required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Health Disparities on the Labor Floor
clinical_study.official_title: Health Disparities on the Labor Floor

brief_summary.textblock: The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) defines a disparity as a difference or a gap that exist between two groups, which is both statistically significant, larger than 10%, and indicates poor quality for the minority (non-referent) group. Despite advances in public health initiatives and medicine, disparities in healthcare are persistent. For example, in the United States, maternal mortality ratio has doubled since 1987 to 2009 where African American women were 4 times as likely to die from childbirth. Although there was no observed racial disparity in maternal deaths at University of Alabama Birmingham, there is anecdotal experience that may suggest health disparities do exist on the labor floor when examining neuraxial utilization and effectiveness. This retrospective study will seek to examine the successful extension of labor analgesia for cesarean section as it relates to insurance status.

primary_outcome.measure: Successful extension of labor epidural catheter for cesarean section
primary_outcome.time_frame: from the time of admission to the time of delivery
primary_outcome.description: labor epidural activation in the setting of cesarean section

intervention.description: Patients will be assessed retrospectively for evidence of successful or failed epidural extension in the setting of need for cesarean section

study_pop.textblock: All women admitted to the labor and delivery unit from 1/1/2015 to 12/31/2019, who meet the above defined inclusion and exclusion criteria

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Pregnancy
- Age >/= age 18 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- Women less than age 18 will be excluded.
